trial_identification.studytitle: In-hospital mortality rates after a cemented femoral component for displaced neck of femur fractures.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A prospective cohort study to investigate in-hospital mortality rates after a cemented femoral component for displaced neck of femur fractures.

interventions.interventions: Fixation with a cemented Exeter femoral component. Currently there is much debate in the orthopaedic community about the standard treatment of these types of fractures and whether the use of cement influences mortality rates. At our institution, all of these fractures are treated with a cemented Exeter femoral component as standard, based on current evidence. However, in order to ensure that this has not resulted in an increase in mortality rate, in-hospital mortality rates were observed to ensure they are within safe limits. Data collected from the period April 2010 (when the Hip Fracture Unit was opened) - July 2012

primaryOutcome.outcome: In-hospital mortality rates assessed via hospital records and orthopaedic audit database. As we are interested in in-hospital mortality, assessment of records within the episode relating to the surgery were examined (including rehab centre if applicable), until discharge home or to a care facility.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: in hospital (including rehab facility) relating to the surgical episode for fracture management

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: all patients presenting with a displaced fractured neck of femur where arthroplasty was indicated
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: fixation by methods other than arthroplasty such as pin and plate or hip scews

trial_design.statisticalmethods: comparison of mortality rates with current published literature. presentation of rates and general demographics

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: The Prince Charles Hospital Rode Road Chermside QLD 4032

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This cohort study aims to investigate the in-hospital mortality of patients with a displaced femoral neck fracture when treated with a cemented femoral component. This un-selected series will be the largest in the current literature. There is some discussion in the orthopaedic community about the role of cement in post-operative mortality. The aim of this study is to examine this more closely in a controlled setting where every patient requiring arthroplasty receives the same cemented prosthesis as standard care.
